title: 105_s494
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and it establishes prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" amends Chapter 303 of title 18, United States Code to include prisoner copayments for health care services. It defines terms like account, Director, health care provider, and health care visit. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines key terms such as health care provider as a licensed person providing health services, health care visit as a prisoner's visit to a health care provider at their request, and prisoner as someone subject to incarceration for criminal violations. The term 'prisoner' refers to individuals in incarceration, detention, or admission to a facility for criminal violations. A 'qualified health care visit' excludes visits during intake, annual examinations. A qualified health care visit excludes routine visits during intake, annual examinations, emergencies, immunizations, visits initiated by prison staff, or referrals from prison officials. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons assesses and collects fees for health care services initiated by staff, referrals from prison officials, or by prisoners who are under 18, pregnant, mentally ill, or disabled. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons assesses and collects fees for health care services for prisoners who are seriously mentally ill or permanently disabled. The fees include a copayment of $3 to $5 for each health care visit and up to $5 for prescription medications provided by a health care provider. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons establishes fees for health care services for prisoners, including copayments for prescription medications and health care visits. The fees are collected from the prisoner's account. Fees are collected from the prisoner's account. If a prisoner inflicts an injury on another prisoner, the responsible party will have to pay the fee for the health care visit related to the injury. The Director establishes fees for health care services for prisoners, collected from their account. Fees for health care visits related to injuries inflicted by a prisoner must be paid, with options for installment payment plans. No treatment can be refused for financial reasons. The Director establishes fees for health care services for prisoners, collected from their account. No treatment can be refused for financial reasons, regardless of the prisoner's ability to pay. Amounts collected are deposited into the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director collects fees for health care services from prisoners' accounts, which are deposited into the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director must report to Congress annually on the amounts collected and the impact of the implementation of this section on health care. The annual report to Congress includes amounts collected and the impact on health care visits by prisoners. Prisoners are required to pay copayments for health care services, with fees collected from their accounts and deposited into the Crime Victims' Fund. The annual report to Congress includes details on the amounts collected and the effect on prisoners' health care visits.
